markdownRemark.html:
Motivating Derivatives

  • Before diving straight into the backpropagation algorithm, we should understand why we care about the partial derivatives ∂J(w,b)∂w\frac{\partial J(w,b)}{\partial w}∂w∂J(w,b)​ and ∂J(w,b)∂b\frac{\partial J(w,b)}{\partial b}∂b∂J(w,b)​
  • Graphing out the computations of derivatives can help us understand the use of partial derivatives
  • Specifically, we'll use a graph to determine the partial derivatives of J(w,b)J(w,b)J(w,b) with respect to bbb and www
  • Essentially, a partial derivative ∂J∂v\frac{\partial J}{\partial v}∂v∂J​ says an increase of ccc in the bottom value vvv will cause the top value JJJ to increase by c×c \timesc× ∂J∂v\frac{\partial J}{\partial v}∂v∂J​

Example of Computing Derivatives

  • Suppose we have the following functions and inputs:

  • Let's focus on the parameter aaa for now
  • Sometimes, we'll want to increase or decrease aaa
  • Changing aaa will also change JJJ as a result
  • Sometimes, we want to know how JJJ changes before we change aaa
  • If we plug 5.0015.0015.001 in for aaa instead of 555, then we'll notice:
a=5→5.001a = 5 \to 5.001a=5→5.001 v=11→11.001v = 11 \to 11.001v=11→11.001 J=33→33.003J = 33 \to 33.003J=33→33.003
  • So, increasing aaa by 0.0010.0010.001 leads to a change in JJJ of 0.0030.0030.003
  • If we change aaa by a large number, then we'll notice:
a=5→15a = 5 \to 15a=5→15 v=11→21v = 11 \to 21v=11→21 J=33→63J = 33 \to 63J=33→63
  • So, increasing aaa by 101010 leads to a change in JJJ of 303030
  • If we keep changing aaa by some value, then we'll notice that JJJ will always increase by 333 times that value
  • In other words, a one-unit increase in aaa will lead to a three-unit increase in JJJ
  • We call this a partial derivative:
∂J∂a=3\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = 3∂a∂J​=3
  • Usually, we don't want to manually adjust aaa and observe changes in JJJ to find the partial derivative
  • Luckily, we can use calculus to determine the partial derivative of some function JJJ with respect to parameter aaa:
J=3v=3a+3bcJ = 3v = 3a + 3bcJ=3v=3a+3bc ∂J∂a=3\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = 3∂a∂J​=3

An Assumption about Derivatives

  • As we saw previously, changing aaa by some amount will lead to a change in JJJ by 333 times that amount
  • Stated another way, the partial derivative ∂J∂a=3\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = 3∂a∂J​=3
  • We can also determine partial derivatives of other values with respect to aaa
  • For example, if we change aaa by 0.0010.0010.001 again, then we'll notice:
a=5→5.001a = 5 \to 5.001a=5→5.001 v=11→11.001v = 11 \to 11.001v=11→11.001
  • So, increasing aaa by 0.0010.0010.001 leads to a change in vvv of 0.0010.0010.001
  • In other words, they change by the same amount
  • Therefore, our partial derivative looks like the following:
∂v∂a=1\frac{\partial v}{\partial a} = 1∂a∂v​=1
  • Notice, vvv can also change if we change bbb or ccc:
v=a+bcv = a + bcv=a+bc
  • Therefore, we're making an assumption when we notice a 0.0010.0010.001 change in vvv with a 0.0010.0010.001 change in aaa
  • Specifically, we're assuming that both bbb and ccc remain fixed
  • The partial derivative ∂v∂a\frac{\partial v}{\partial a}∂a∂v​ makes this assumption as well
  • In other words, all partial derivates nudge the input associated with the denominator, observe changes in the function associated with the numerator, and hold all other parameters and functions fixed

Observing the Chain Rule

  • We've already noticed the relationship between aaa, vvv, and JJJ when we made a change to aaa and observed the change in JJJ:
a=5→5.001a = 5 \to 5.001a=5→5.001 v=11→11.001v = 11 \to 11.001v=11→11.001 J=33→33.003J = 33 \to 33.003J=33→33.003
  • From this, we've seen that ∂J∂a=3\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = 3∂a∂J​=3 because aaa influences vvv, and vvv influences JJJ
a→v→Ja \to v \to Ja→v→J
  • In other words, partial derivatives are dependent on both the direct and indirect effects of parameters
  • This concept is captured by the chain rule:
∂J∂a=∂J∂v∂v∂a\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = \frac{\partial J}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial a}∂a∂J​=∂v∂J​∂a∂v​ ∂J∂a=3×1=3\frac{\partial J}{\partial a} = 3 \times 1 = 3∂a∂J​=3×1=3
  • The chain rule is the calculus we used for computing our partial derivatives previously
  • This is a major step in the backpropagation algorithm

tldr

  • A partial derivative ∂J∂v\frac{\partial J}{\partial v}∂v∂J​ says an increase of ccc in the bottom value vvv will cause the top value JJJ to increase by c×c \timesc× ∂J∂v\frac{\partial J}{\partial v}∂v∂J​
  • All partial derivates are an observed change in the function associated with the numerator

  • All partial derivatives find this change by:

    • Nudging the input associated with the denominator
    • Holding all other parameters and functions fixed
  • The chain rule is a formula to compute the partial derivatives
  • Its formula shows that partial derivatives are influenced by the direct and indirect changes of dependent parameters

References

  • Derivatives with Computation Graphs
  • Forward Propagation and Backware Propagation
